Hi, My Name is Craigslist Jesse

  • warning: fopen() [function.fopen]: Filename cannot be empty in /nfs/c04/h01/mnt/66721/domains/themonthlychallenge.com/tags/release-1.1/includes/file.inc on line 757.
  • The file could not be created.
  • warning: fopen() [function.fopen]: Filename cannot be empty in /nfs/c04/h01/mnt/66721/domains/themonthlychallenge.com/tags/release-1.1/includes/file.inc on line 757.
  • The file could not be created.
  • warning: fopen() [function.fopen]: Filename cannot be empty in /nfs/c04/h01/mnt/66721/domains/themonthlychallenge.com/tags/release-1.1/includes/file.inc on line 757.
  • The file could not be created.
Wed, 01/28/2009 - 21:46 | by Jesse

I just got back from my craigslist date, and it was a pretty decent time. We met up at Gin Sushi in Pasadena after work (which by the way, I wouldn't really recommend.) Even though I got lost on the way there, I still managed to make it there before my date and was waiting in the restaurant for a little while before she got there.

After the second set of patrons to come through the door failed to be my date, I began getting really nervous. What if I don't recognize her? Do I shake her hand when she comes in or do we hug? But I'm a terrible hugger! What if she stands me up? What if I get stood up by a craigslist date! I'm a loser! Fortunately, she showed up before I had a nervous breakdown and was surprisingly laid back and cool.

The date itself was pretty typical - talking, laughing, getting to know each other, and maybe one or two awkward silences - but it was a good time. She wasn't internet girlfriend material (whatever that means), but she was a fun girl. If I were hanging out in Pasadena, I'd call her up to hang out and drink some beers.

So, rather than fill my blog with a description of how extremely (and somewhat disappointingly?) normal the craigslist date was, here's a recap of some of the worst emails I received during the month of January in response to craigslist personal ads.

Danielle

Danielle responded to one of my ads and seemed like a pretty cool Silverlake girl. Unfortunately, after email #1, her ability to construct coherent sentences plummeted.

[...]

So what are you about? What kind of music do you like? What do you do for fun? Where do you work? Do you live alone or w/roommates? Do you have aim/yahoo? Do you have any more pictures &/or a myspace?

Hope you had a good wknd.

- Danielle

Really? You can't type out the full word weekend? That combined with the fact that she wrote like a high school girl led to an abandoned conversation. Then a few days later, I get another message:

Jesse! I haven't heard from you. Busy? Over it? :)

Hope you had a good wknd.

- Danielle

Sorry, Danielle. I didn't have the heart to tell you that the reason I stopped e-mailing you was because you can't spell. And also, I'm petty.

A.S.

Then there was "A.S." We exchanged a few emails, but it wasn't that interesting. Naturally, I lost interest. A few weeks later, January was drawing to a close. Out of desperation, I posted another ad on craigslist - this time with a picture. Now, I had sent the exact same picture to "A.S" earlier in the month while we were still conversing. But when she found my second ad, she decided to reply to that one too.

Kudos for posting a picture. It's an excellent one at that and that was a well thought out post.

Just sending you some positive vibes.

She knew it was me, and knew that we had stopped talking - why would she reply to that second ad? Was she some crazy craigslist stalker? I was weirded out...

Amy

So don't assume that I'm some kind of internet dating asshole - I was also given the shaft a few times. I guess my ravishing good looks are just a bit too much for some people.

[...]

Do you have any pictures to prove these ravishing good looks by any chance? I promise I'm not a perverted old man who rapes young lads, or a crazy woman truck driver named Hildagard or anything... :(

After a few messages to make sure that she wasn't, in fact, Hildagard the truck driver, I ended up sending Amy a picture in order to prove my studliness. She never replied back and I cried myself to sleep three nights in a row.

The Lesbians

The best emails may have been the set of responses I received (almost immediately) after accidentally posting an ad in the "women seeking women" section. It took me a while to figure out why so many lesbians wanted me, but eventually I realized that it was just because I'm an idiot and not because I have magical powers to convert gays.

The first email was from "Pierced Kitty." The weird part was that if it was spam, it was terrible spam. There were no links in the message and the phone number she left didn't even have an area code! What is this, 1989?

Hi, I read your ad at Craigslist. I was born and raised here. But moved away for a few years and found by way back. I love having fun and laughing.

Call me 727-****. I hope to hear from you soon.

Then I got a bunch of lesbian spam emails (I had no idea those existed!) followed by the legit email which tipped me off:

Hola,

I found your ad very original, I really enjoyed reading it. Okay Ms Genuine, funny and smart lady, tell me what you are looking for?

I am a Hispanic, petit, femme, slim lesbian that likes to laugh, drama free, sane and loves to enjoy life and have a good laugh. I'm spontaneous and like to explore LA.

Attached is my picture, this is the only pic that fit the CL file size settings. If you are interested and want to see more pictures let me know.

Hasta luego

...and then?

And then there were all of the uglies. I'm not out to hurt or embarass anyone (except for myself, I guess) so I'll just say that there were a lot of replies from ladies who were...unfortunate looking. I won't post any of the pictures or emails up here, but expect to get a lot of them if you ever decide to look for love on the internets.

I didn't expect internet dating to be so time consuming, but it's hard to find semi-attractive, interesting people who aren't crazy - it took me almost a full month. I thought technology was supposed to make life easier!?!
